All freight transported by this Company is subject to its published terms and regulations. All claims for overcharge must be sent to the Freight Claims Auditor, Montreal, accompanied by freight bill.    I was in my teens, 18 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To get land to make a home.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

    Walking to another young man who had been west in 1901 and came home to see his parents in Windsor, Ont. 1901-1902 at Cardinal, Ont.

2329 Smith Rd., Regina, Sask.

Yes, my brother and his family.

David Samuel Simmon

Shrewsbury, 1905, settled on a homestead 71 W. 1/4

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Our table was a hole dug out of the side of a small hill, cedar poles brought from Montana put in ground and board on the sides. This was made of poplar poles with alder hay spread on. Our living quarters was a quinney 4 X 16 with 3 feet boarded off to hold outs for 4 horses, two cows, our bed, stove, table, churn, sideboard to hold clothing.

If a young married couple lives that way for a start.

Had to travel to Medicine Hat for any supplies about 467 miles no other than we had to.

"My pioneering experiences in Indian Head"

That's what they call us!

Indian Head

Experimental Farm employee for stock at Col., times and many available immediately.

TO REGINA

BRIANTS

The summer of 1890 was a busy one for all of us, seeding the crop, breaking up new land and planting forage crops. The fall was spent in harvesting and storing the grain. We had to put up hay and wood to keep the animals comfortable through the winter.

In the fall of 1890, we moved into our new home in Regina. The house was a two-story frame structure with a large porch on the front. It had four bedrooms, two bathrooms, and a large living room. We also had a garage attached to the side of the house.

The next spring, we planted more crops and harvested them again in the fall. We continued to work hard on the farm throughout the year, despite the challenges of farming in the semi-arid climate.
"My pioneering experiences in Indian Head"

That's what they call us!

Indian Head

First Prize Essay

The following story, submitted by W.D. Lang of Caveston, B.C., took first prize, $5, in Indian Head's Golden Jubilee contest.

One of the most interesting stories I ever heard was told to me by an old timer who had lived through the early days of Indian Head. He said that when he first came to town, there were only a few houses and a small population. The town was growing slowly, but there was a lot of potential for growth.

In those early days, the town was very isolated from the rest of the world. There were no roads or bridges, and travel was difficult. However, the people of Indian Head were determined to make their mark on the world.

One day, a group of pioneers decided to set out on a journey to find a new home. They loaded up their wagons with supplies and set off into the wilderness. After many days of travel, they finally arrived at their destination.

They found a beautiful valley surrounded by mountains. They built their homes and started farming. Over time, the town grew and prospered.

Today, Indian Head is a thriving community with a rich history. It is a place where people come to experience the beauty of nature and the warmth of its people.

TO REGINA

BRIANTS

Experimental Farm employee for stock at C.M. times and many valuable services rendered.

Hours Counted to Big Jubilee Celebration

Indian Head's 50th birthday celebration now needs only fair weather next Tuesday, July 1 to assure recognition of the event by the community. The hours until the Golden Jubilee celebration will be counted down by the Indian Head Legion branch and Rockets, plus farm groups and other organizations.

Athletic association officials, in top charge, had the ball rolling on the sports program. The Legion has scheduled an outstanding milestone in Indian Head's history.

RINK JOB STARTED

Work on the new rink is progressing steadily. The work involves heating and lighting, and the installation of the ice-making machinery. The work is being done by local firms.

TRIBUTE TO PETTY

More than 200 people attended the tribute to Petty at the Legion Hall last Friday night. The tribute was held in memory of Petty, who died recently.

LAST FOR SENDALL

This Coming Sunday

In keeping with the theme of the Jubilee celebration, members of the Church and other friends pack their bags and head for Regina. The event will be held at the Regina Exhibition Grounds.

MINISTER BURIED

Rev. R. L. Landheer, pastor of the First United Church, was buried yesterday afternoon at the Regina Cemetery. He died on Friday.

BRIDE-ELECT HONORED IN SHOWER

Miss Mary Smith, who will be married to Mr. Smith next week, was honored in a shower held at the home of Mrs. Smith.

CADETS LEAVE FOR DUNDURN CAMP

The cadets left for Dundurn Camp today. They will spend the next few weeks there.

WINNERS PICKED IN ESSAY CONTEST

Winners of the essay contest have been selected. The winners will be announced soon.

"MY PIONEERING EXPERIENCES IN INDIAN HEAD"

First Prize Essay

The following essay, submitted by W. D. Long of Carleton, B.C., has been selected as the first prize essay:

"I was born in 1900 in Indian Head, Saskatchewan. I grew up there and still live there. I have lived through many changes in my life, but I have always been proud to be an Indian Header.

"In the spring of 1920 I graduated from high school. I then went to work for the Canadian Pacific Railway. I worked there for many years and became quite proficient in my job.

"In the fall of 1930 I married Miss Mary Smith. We moved to Regina where we lived for many years. We had two children, a boy and a girl.

"We returned to Indian Head in 1940 where we still live. We have enjoyed our time here and have made many friends.

"I am proud to be an Indian Header and I hope to continue living here for many more years."
That’s what they call us!

Indian Head, which this year celebrates its 25th anniversary, began as an hotel known as Scratch’El-Elk or “wild rice” camp. It was called “wild rice” because it was located in the center of a cornfield instead of near a river.

More than two decades ago Dr. John Farrar purchased the land and built a house on it. The farm was run by Dr. Farrar’s wife until his death in 1899.

The property then passed into the hands of Dr. Edward Davies, who sold it to Mr. Edmondson. Mr. Edmondson sold it to Mr. Billingsly, who lived there until his death in 1916.

The property was then bought by Mr. Simpson and was held by him until his death.

Mr. Simpson’s widow continued to live there until she died in 1940.

Since then, the property has remained in Mr. Simpson’s family.

“My pioneering experiences in Indian Head”

First Prize Essay

The following story, submitted by Mr. W. A., took first prize, $5, in Indian Head’s candlelight essay competition.

Cadets Leave For Dundurn Camp

The cadets of the district will attend a training camp this summer at Dundurn Camp. The camp is located approximately three miles from Hamilton, Ontario.

An interview with Mayor O’Connell shows that he is very interested in the development of the town. He has promised to work hard to bring prosperity to the community.

Hours Counted to Big Jubilee Celebration

Indian Head's 50th birthday celebration now needs only fair weather next Tuesday, July 1, to assure residents and visitors that the community counted the hours until the Golden Jubilee event.

Athletic association officials in top charge had the honour of announcing that the Indian Legion branch and Rockets, plus farm groups and throngs of individuals, are preparing plans for what is expected to be an outstanding milestone in Indian Head's life.

RINK JOB STARTED

Work has been started on the new rink, which will be completed by the end of June. According to the general manager, the work will be finished by the end of June.

Last For Sendall

Minister Buried

Large Stone Home Is Little Bit Of Old England At Moosomin, Sask.

MOOSOMIN, Sask.—'The Maples' of Moosomin stands solid and enduring. A handsome, 10-roomed natural stone house in wide wooded grounds, the mansion is a little bit of old England. The Victorian flavor of the big stone house starts with the riding crop in the hallway, carried past the steeplechase pictures and into the den where the squire smokes his pipe and a visitor examines a Malayan kris on the library wall.

The squire of Maples is 82-year-old Kenneth Price, London-born and Oxford-nurtured, who began life as the son of an imperial army officer. He changed his mind about an army career and in 1887 turned his back on the white cliffs of Dover—but not its traditions—to become a farmer at Cannington Manor, Sask.

After his home at Cannington burned down he worked in a livery stable at Moosomin and part of his job was driving the mail and passenger coaches over the old Moose Mountain trail to Birtle, Man. His parents, sisters and brothers came out in 1889 and they settled on a farm near here.

The restless Price however was a timber cruiser in northern Manitoba when the First World War broke out, and he became Captain Price with a squadron of the 9th Canadian Mounted Rifles that served overseas. He was gassed in France and after months of hospital care found his way back to Moosomin, where he served as postmaster for the next 30 years.

Mr. Price has been astride a horse most of his 82 years. He staged his own fox hunts in the Moosomin district with hounds imported from England. Polo was another pastime he brought to the prairie west but jumping was his favorite sport.

He took five horses to Winnipeg one year and won every steeplechase prize offered. Mr. Price has been a top-notch cricket player, representing Saskatchewan in other parts of Canada.

He was the first secretary of the Martin municipality and president of the Dominion Postmasters' Association for a five-year term. He retired from the Moosomin post office in 1950.

Squire Price now is holding the fort for merrie England at Moosomin and confidently looks forward to celebrating his first century at his beloved Maples.

A water moccasin can bite under water, but is less likely to be annoyed into striking while in the water.

Buffalo Are Attraction At Waterton Lakes National Park

Waterton Lakes, Alta.—Buffalo herds have returned to the rolling prairie of Waterton Lakes National Park. This is the first time in more than a century that the area has been visited by such large herds.

The buffalo are attracted to the park by the abundant grasses and the absence of hunting. The herds are now being studied by scientists from the University of Alberta.

Saskatchewan farm workers may be called up for military service.

Canada's wild animals, birds, constitute some of its greatest attractions.

Here's Some Quick and Appetizing Sandwiches

For The Picnic

Honey Butter

1 cup honey (melted)
Mix honey and butter together until thoroughly blended. Put in a covered container, hot or cold.

Cheese and Egg Spread

1 tablespoon fat
1 tablespoon sugar
1/2 teaspoon mustard
1/4 cup milk
1/4 cup vinegar
Melt fat, add sugar, mustard, milk and vinegar. Mix well.

Cinnamon Honey Spread

1/2 cup honey
Mix honey and butter as for honey butter, then add cinnamon. Store in covered jar.

Spanish Sandwich Spread

1 tablespoon chopped onion
1 tablespoon minced garlic
1/2 cup grated cheese
Dash of paprika
Mix onion, garlic, cheese and paprika. Store in covered jar.

Meat and Olive Spread

2 cups ground bologna or cooked ham
2 cloves minced garlic
1/4 cup mayonnaise
Combine all ingredients. Mix well.

Chopped Meat Sandwich

1 hard-cooked egg
1/2 cup mayonnaise
1/2 cup chopped pickles
Mix all ingredients together.

Eggs and Bacon Sandwich

3 hard-boiled eggs
3 slices bacon, fried brown
Spread on generously buttered bread.

Tuna-Apple Filling

1 cup tuna, chopped
1/2 cup apples, chopped
1/4 cup mayonnaise
Mix all ingredients together.

Printer With A Few Drinks

Tourist Right
Here's Some Quick and Appetizing Sandwiches

For The Picnic

Honey Butter

1 cup honey (family size)

Pinwheel Sandwich

1/2 inch thick bread, cut lengthwise into strips

1/4 cup butter

Mix honey and butter together until smooth.

Spread mixture evenly over bread slices.

Roll up tightly and slice into rounds.

Chase and Egg Spread

1 tablespoon fat

1 tablespoon mayonnaise

1/2 teaspoon sugar

1/2 teaspoon vinegar

Melt fat in a small saucepan.

Add remaining ingredients and mix well.

Simmer until thickened.

Cool and spread on toast or crackers.

Spanish Honey Spread

1/2 cup honey

1/2 cup ground cheese

Mix honey and cheese until smooth.

Spread on toast or crackers.

Meat and Olive Spread

1 hard-cooked egg

2 cups ground bologna

1/2 cup mayonnaise

1/2 cup chopped olives

Mix all ingredients together.

Spread on toast or crackers.

Salmon and Horseradish

1/2 hard-cooked egg

1 tablespoon horseradish

1/2 cup canned salmon

1/2 cup mayonnaise

Mix all ingredients together.

Spread on toast or crackers.

Chopped Meat Sandwich

1 hard-cooked egg

1 tablespoon mustard

1/2 cup chopped meat

1/2 cup mayonnaise

Mix all ingredients together.

Spread on toast or crackers.

Eggs and Bacon Sandwich

3 hard-boiled eggs

3 bacon slices

1/2 cup mayonnaise

Mix all ingredients together.

Spread on toast or crackers.
